text.headline: THOREAU'S MAP OF MOUNT MONADNOCK
text.text:
In early August of 1862, Henry David Thoreau climbed Mount Monadnock in New Hampshire, one of his favorite mountains, accompanied by his friend Ellery Channing. Thoreau took bearings from the summit and later used these to sketch a map that he included in his Journal entry for August 9. This map tour highlights several features of Thoreau's map.

In the Journal, the map appears upside-down in relation to the text on the preceding page. That's most likely because Thoreau began by using the bearings he'd taken, drawing the landscape as it appeared from his south-facing view at the summit. This put South at the top of the map, contrary to convention. Eventually, Thoreau rotated the map 180 degrees to add many of his labels. For the purposes of this tour, the map at left has also been rotated so that North is at top and the labels are easier to read.

Thoreau's map is much more than a simple freehand rendering. Only a cartographer or skilled surveyor could produce work of this quality. Owing to the compass bearings Thoreau took from the summit on August 8 and a linear measurement methodology he developed, the map's scale is true and the angles of its bearing lines are precise.

As you move through this tour of Thoreau's map, you'll zoom in on selected features, but you can always click-hold-drag to move around in the map and explore.

text.headline: TAKING MEASUREMENTS
text.text:
The basis of my map was the distance from the summit to the second camp, made by rudely casting a stone before. Pacing the distance of an easy cast, I found it about ten rods, and thirteen such stone’s throws, or one hundred and thirty rods, carried me to the camp. As I had the course, from the summit, and from the camp, of the principal points, I could tell the rest nearly enough. It was about fifty rods from the summit to the ravine and eighty more to the camp. (H. D. Thoreau, The Journal of Henry D. Thoreau, XIV:39)

On the map, Thoreau has drawn a bearing line from the summit (labeled Peak) 130 rods southeast towards the location makred 2D Camp, labeling the line S40E. (At lower right on the map, he's indicated that the map's scale is 80 rods to the inch.)

media.caption: Thoreau indicates the map's scale at the lower right of the page (when North is at top)
Near the head of the White Dot Trail.

text.headline: FIRST CAMP
text.text:
From left to to right we see Thoreau's bearing line labeled S5W, his marking for South (S, and a dotted circle with a point at its center and a small triangle to the left (west) of it, labeled 1st Camp. The camp, then, would have been approximately S6E from the summit.

The dotted circle and point mark the rocky mesa near the camp. The triangle may represent the spruce lean-to in which Thoreau slept. In a letter to H. G. O. Blake, his companion on his previous, 1858, trip to Monadnock, he referred to this site as that memorable stone 'chunk yard,' in which we made our camp.

An important feature not distinguishable on the printed map as it appears in Houghton Mifflin's 1906 edition of Thoreau's collected writings, or in any other printed version, is the penciled word Ravine inside Thoreau's ink label Swamp. While no map or book cites this ravine as a notable feature, there is no question about its presence when reaching the summit via the eastern approaches. On both the Pumpelly Trail and the White Dot Trail, visitors make a steep and rocky descent at about 2,800 feet prior to the final steep ascent up the rocks to the summit.

The curved line to the right of the word extending northeast from the end of the word Ravine, then curving westward as it passes Peak (see detail below), marks the ravine itself. That marking is important because it establishes the location of Thoreau's first camp as being west of the stream that runs down the middle of the ravine and also south of the rocky cap—most likely just off the Paradise Valley Trail.

media.caption: Th summit in mid-March. <q>Pumpelly</q> has been written on one of the rocks.

text.headline: NORTHEAST SPUR SUMMIT
text.text: Today, the Pumpelly trail runs over the location Thoreau has marked <q>NE Spur Summit</q> in ink over pencil. Along that ridge, the first high point or summit is now referred to as Town Line Peak. At 2,920 feet, it's the high point of Pumpelly Trail situated at the Jaffrey-Dublin town line. This ridge has three <q>summits,</q> each lower than the one preceding it. Thoreau has marked the second in pencil as <q>2D summit.</q> To the south of <q>NE Spur summit,</q> Thoreau has indicated the presence of two swamps. By the largest of these he's written, in ink, <q>NE Swamp.</q> Today, that swamp is known as <q>Thoreau Bog.</q> A line, first dotted and then solid, runs from that swamp north towards the village of Dublin (not indicated on the map). The name of that stream is Mountain Brook. The smaller swamp is on the southern side of the ridge and is marked but not labeled. From that swamp a runs a line to the southeast representing Ark Brook.

media.caption: This is a placeholder image for one of Meads Brook

text.headline: MEADS BROOK
text.text:
Two other streams are noted on the map. In the southeast quadrant, A solid inked line runs from the ravine and the swamps in a southeasterly direction. The name of that stream is Meads Brook, and it's most likely the stream for which Thoreau wrote that he wanted to observe its source on his next visit (see Journal, XIV:52).
N. B. – Observe next time: the source of the stream which crosses the path; what species of swallow flies over mountain; what the grass which gives the pastures a yellowish color seen from the summit.

text.headline: FASSETT BROOK
text.text: In the southwest quadrant, west of where Thoreau has marked <q>South Spur Brow</q> in ink (the location is now referred to as <q>Point Surprise</q>) a solid line runs north-south with a small bend at the top. That solid line represents Fassett Brook. It runs off the mountain south to the Troy Reservoir and thence to Perkins Pond.

media.caption: This is a placeholder image for one of Fassett Brook

text.headline: PASSING THROUGH THE PLATEAU
text.text: From <q>2D Camp,</q> a dotted line runs to the northeast towards <q>NE Swamp</q> and <q>NE Spur Summit.</q> The line marks Thoreau's path  through the area he called <q>the plateau.</q> It crosses the high point of the eastern spur, which Thoreau did not name or identify other than to write that it was where he would walk each morning to view the sunrise.

media.caption: This is a placeholder image for one of the plateau

text.headline: PATH TO THE SUMMIT
text.text: Passing between the S45W and the S5W bearing lines (in the southwest corner of the map), Thoreau drew a dotted line in ink crossing Fassett Brook and continuing towards 1st Camp. The line marks what is now called the Paradise Valley Trail. It passes 1st Camp and continues through the Ravine and the swamp, winding its way to the summit. (See map detail below.) This is the trail Thoreau forged from the base of the mountain all the way to the Peak.
